title: Surging Ethane Demand to Trigger Big Gas-Carrier Orders
text:
Ship owners are likely to order up to 40 large ethane carriers over the next 12 months as demand for the gas widely used in the petrochemical industry to make plastics and detergents steadily rises.

The American Bureau of Shipping, a maritime standards-setting group, told the Gastech conference in Houston that American shale production has significantly reduced ethane costs, making the U.S. the world’s biggest exporter of the gas.

U.S. producers are looking to sign more contracts with clients in Asia and South America, said ABS Global Gas Solutions Director Aditya Aggarwal. “We do see volumes growing and the transportation infrastructure building up and becoming more mature. This is just the beginning,” he said.

Mr. Aggarwal said global exports have risen in the past six years from zero to eight million metric tons annually. With a number of U.S.projects expected to go online in the next couple of years, export capacity could double relatively quickly.

“The current market is small but there is a potential for almost 40 ships to be ordered in the next year,” Mr. Aggarwal said.

The U.S. began exporting ethane via pipeline to Nova Chemicals Corp.’s Sarnia plants in Canada in early 2014, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

The first seaborne ethane cargo was loaded from Norway in March 2016 to India, which has since also started taking cargoes from the U.S. The U.K, Sweden, Mexico and Brazil are also importing U.S. ethane.

Norway is the only other major exporter.

Big ethane carriers cost around $120 million each and are mostly made at South Korean yards

Among major exporters, Texas-based Energy Transfer Partners, parent company of Sunoco Logistics Partners LP, is building a second ethane terminal in Nederland, Texas, along the U.S. Gulf Coast.

The terminal which is slated to be completed in 2020, will have the capacity to export 175,000 barrels a day, with 150,000 barrels already committed to China’s Zhejiang Satellite Petrochemical Co., one of the world’s biggest acrylics manufacturers.
